<Summary source="https://defirate.com/prediction-markets/world-cup-odds/">
# Summary of Article: "2026 World Cup Odds"

**Source:** DeFi Rate (prediction market analysis)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### Market Developments (Feb 8-15):
- **New markets launched:** Kalshi added stage qualification contracts (Round of 16, quarterfinals, semifinals, final); Polymarket added group winner markets for all 12 groups
- **Total volume:** Over $4.8 million on Kalshi alone for the outright winner market

### Outright Winner Probabilities (VWAP - Volume Weighted Average Price):

**Top Contenders:**
- **Spain:** 15.9% VWAP (18.5% Kalshi, 15.5% Polymarket) - consensus favorite
- **England:** 13.5% VWAP (12.5% Kalshi, 13.5% Polymarket) - second choice; $31.6K volume
- **France:** 11.5% VWAP (11.5% both platforms) - third place; $21.3K volume

**Week's Biggest Movers (Feb 8-15):**
- Brazil: dropped from 9.5% to 8.6% (-0.9%)
- Argentina: fell from 10.2% to 9.5% (-0.7%)
- France: declined from 12.3% to 11.5% (-0.8%)
- Portugal: rose from 7.1% to 7.4% (+0.3%)
- Netherlands: increased from 3.3% to 3.5% (+0.2%)
- Italy: climbed from 1.8% to 2.0% (+0.2%)

**Co-Hosts:**
- USA: 3% Kalshi, 2% Polymarket
- Mexico: 2% Kalshi, 1% Polymarket
- Canada: <1% Kalshi, 1% Polymarket

### Market Context:
- Polymarket currently dominates volume (e.g., England has $31.2K on Polymarket vs $360 on Kalshi)
- Only 8 countries have ever won the World Cup since 1930 (Uruguay, Italy, Germany, Brazil, England, Argentina, France, Spain)
- Spain became favorite after winning Euro 2024, beating England, France, and Germany

**Note:** This article focuses on prediction market odds and does not provide independent analysis of team performance or tournament outcomes. All probabilities reflect market prices on prediction platforms as of mid-February 2026.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.goal.com/en-us/betting/world-cup-winner-odds/blt4b7e4ceb80cb6863">
# Summary of Article: World Cup 2026 Winner Odds

**Source:** Goal.com US  
**Date:** December 04, 2025  
**Author:** Mark Richard Sochon

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Current Favorites (as of December 2025):**
  - Spain tops the betting charts as favorites
  - England is positioned as a strong contender with each-way value
  - France and Argentina are also among the top favorites
  - The article notes odds will fluctuate frequently before the tournament

- **Tournament Details:**
  - 48 teams participating (expanded format)
  - Tournament dates: June 11 to July 19, 2026
  - Hosted by Canada, Mexico, and United States
  - Final will be held in New Jersey

- **Historical Context:**
  - Only 8 countries have ever won the World Cup since 1930
  - England's only World Cup win was in 1966

## Analysis of Top Contenders:

**Spain:**
- Won Euro 2024
- Strong squad depth
- Potential weakness: vulnerable defense
- Key players: Nico Williams, Lamine Yamal

**England:**
- New manager Thomas Tuchel implementing high-intensity style
- Deep attacking options (Cole Palmer, Phil Foden, Morgan Rogers, Eberechi Eze, Bukayo Saka, Jude Bellingham)
- Harry Kane remains main goal threat
- Concerns: Hot conditions may not suit high-intensity style; 60 years without a World Cup final appearance

**France:**
- Structured around Kylian Mbappe
- Won 2018 World Cup, reached 2022 final
- Concerns: Defensive flaws exposed by Spain; underperformed at Euro 2024

**Argentina:**
- Defending champions from 2022
- Won 2024 Copa America
- Lionel Messi will be 39 at tournament
- Concerns: Defensive vulnerabilities; reliance on aging Messi

## Dark Horse Candidates:

**Norway:**
- Not qualified for major tournament since 2000
- Strong qualifying campaign (scored 7 against Italy)
- Erling Haaland as key striker
- Potential value to reach quarter-finals or semi-finals

**Colombia:**
- Never made it past quarter-finals at World Cup
- Reached 2024 Copa America final
- Key players: Luis Diaz, James Rodriguez, Jhon Duran

**Belgium:**
- Golden generation past its prime
- Emerging talents like Jeremy Doku
- Experienced players: Thibaut Courtois, Kevin De Bruyne, Youri Tielemans

## Betting Insights (Opinion from article):

- The World Cup "tends to be won by one of the favourites"
- Only 8 teams have ever won it historically
- Article advises hedging bets on multiple teams
- Suggests using each-way or "to reach semi-final" markets for better value
- Notes that backing dark horses for outright victory may not be advisable given historical patterns
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.fanduel.com/research/2026-world-cup-odds-who-are-the-favorites-to-win-it-all">
## Summary of Article

**Source:** FanDuel Research  
**Date:** February 09, 2026

### Key Information:

**Article Content:**
This article announces that the 2026 World Cup is approaching and references FanDuel Sportsbook's odds for which teams are favorites to win the tournament. 

**Notable Limitation:**
The article does not actually provide the specific odds or list which teams are the favorites. It only mentions that "here are the teams with the best odds to win the World Cup" and references "Full World Cup winner odds at FanDuel Sportsbook," but the extracted content does not include this data. The article appears to be primarily promotional in nature, directing readers to check FanDuel Sportsbook for the actual odds and betting options.

**Disclaimer:** The extracted content appears incomplete, as it references odds and a list of favorites that are not included in the provided text. The actual betting odds that would be relevant to assessing which countries are favored (and thus whether a first-time winner is likely) are not present in this extraction.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.espn.com/soccer/story/_/id/47211639/2026-world-cup-draw-groups-takeaways-predictions-see-games">
# Article Summary: 2026 World Cup predictions: Group-by-group takeaways, must-see games

**Source:** ESPN.com  
**Date:** 74 days ago (from time of extraction)  
**Author:** ESPN

## Key Facts and Information:

### Tournament Details:
- The 2026 FIFA World Cup groups have been set following Friday's draw
- The tournament will be held next summer (2026)
- The U.S. will face Paraguay in their first World Cup match on home soil in 32 years
- Notable matchups include: Kylian Mbappé (France) vs. Erling Haaland (Norway), and England vs. Croatia (rematch of their 2018 semifinal)

### Group A Analysis:
- **Teams:** Mexico, South Africa, South Korea, Winner of UEFA Playoff D (Denmark, North Macedonia, Czech Republic, or Republic of Ireland)
- **FIFA Rankings:** Mexico (15th), South Korea (22nd), Denmark (21st), South Africa (61st)
- **Key observations:** 
  - Mexico hasn't beaten anyone since the Gold Cup final
  - South Korea sailed through Asian qualifying undefeated
  - Denmark is considered the most formidable potential UEFA playoff qualifier
- **Predicted finish:** Mexico, South Korea, UEFA Playoff D, South Africa
- **Best match:** Mexico vs. South Korea in Zapopan

### Group B Analysis:
- **Teams:** Canada, Switzerland, Qatar, Winner of UEFA Playoff A (Italy, Northern Ireland, Wales, or Bosnia and Herzegovina)
- **FIFA Rankings:** Switzerland (17th), Canada (27th), Qatar (51st)
- **Key observations:**
  - Canada has lost every match at their previous two World Cups
  - Qatar is coached by Julen Lopetegui (former West Ham manager)
  - Switzerland is unbeaten in qualifying with four wins and two draws
  - Canada has conceded just one goal in their six friendlies
  - Alphonso Davies (Bayern Munich) is recovering from ACL injury suffered in March
- **Predicted finish:** Switzerland, Canada, UEFA Playoff A, Qatar
- **X factor:** Alphonso Davies' fitness and form

### Group C Analysis:
- **Teams:** Brazil, Morocco, Scotland, Haiti
- **Key observations:**
  - Morocco reached the 2022 World Cup semifinals (first African nation to do so)
  - Haiti appearing in first World Cup since 1974
  - Scotland back for first time since 1998
  - Brazil coached by Carlo Ancelotti, hired to win their sixth World Cup
  - Brazil hasn't won the World Cup since 2002
  - Achraf Hakimi (PSG) is Morocco's star right back
- **Best match:** Brazil vs. Morocco
- **Assessment:** Group should be decided by Brazil-Morocco clash; Morocco seen as dangerous second seed

**Note:** The article appears to continue beyond the extracted content, covering additional groups (D through L are mentioned in the jump-to section but not included in the extraction).
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.foxsports.com/stories/soccer/world-cup-2026-odds">
# Article Summary: 2026 World Cup Odds

**Source:** Fox Sports (as of December 5, 2025)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### Tournament Details:
- The 2026 FIFA World Cup will be the first 48-team edition
- Hosted in North America (Canada, Mexico, United States)
- Tournament runs June 11 - July 19, 2026
- Final will be held at MetLife Stadium in New Jersey

### Betting Odds (via DraftKings Sportsbook):

**Top Favorites (all previous winners):**
- Spain: +450
- England: +550
- France: +750
- Brazil: +800
- Argentina: +800
- Portugal: +1000
- Germany: +1200

**Countries that have never won (selected):**
- Netherlands: +2000
- Norway: +2800
- Belgium: +4000
- Colombia: +5000
- United States: +8000
- Switzerland: +8000
- Morocco: +8000
- Ecuador: +8000
- Mexico: +8000
- Croatia: +10000
- Japan: +10000
- Senegal: +12000

### Historical Context:
- Only 8 countries have ever won the World Cup since 1930
- Previous winners mentioned: Uruguay (1930, 1950), Italy, Germany (4 titles, most recent 2014), Brazil (5 titles, most recent 2002), England (1966), Argentina (3 titles, most recent 2022), France (1998, 2018), Spain (2010)

### Notable Team Information:
- Morocco achieved its best-ever finish in 2022, reaching the semifinals (never won)
- Netherlands has been runner-up three times (1974, 1978, 2010) but never won
- Colombia's best finish was quarterfinals in 2014 (never won)

**Note:** The article provides comprehensive odds and team profiles but does not include expert predictions or analysis about the likelihood of a first-time winner.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.si.com/soccer/favorites-win-2026-world-cup-ranked">
# Summary of Article: "The 10 Favorites to Win the 2026 World Cup—Ranked"

**Source:** Sports Illustrated  
**Date:** November 17, 2025

## Key Facts and Rankings:

The article ranks the top 10 favorites to win the 2026 FIFA World Cup, which will be held in the U.S., Mexico, and Canada from June 11 to July 19, 2026. The tournament will feature 48 nations in a newly-expanded format.

### Countries Ranked (in ascending order of favoritism):

**10. Italy** (4-time world champions)
- Failed to qualify for last two tournaments but won Euro 2020
- Under new management: Gennaro Gattuso replaced Luciano Spalletti in June
- Not yet qualified - must compete in playoffs after finishing behind Norway in qualifying

**9. Uruguay** (2-time world champions)
- Last won in 1950; haven't reached final since then
- Qualified in September 2025
- Beat both Argentina and Brazil during qualifying
- Managed by Marcelo Bielsa

**8. Netherlands**
- Never won a World Cup (three-time losing finalists)
- Manager: Ronald Koeman
- Reached semifinals at Euro 2024
- Issues noted: defensive organization and lack of elite striker

**7. Germany** (won in 2014)
- Failed to advance past group stage in 2018 and 2022 World Cups
- Lost at quarterfinals of Euro 2024 on home soil
- Manager: Julian Nagelsmann
- Concerns about defense and goalkeeper positions

**6. Brazil** (5-time world champions)
- Haven't reached final since 2002
- Eliminated at quarterfinals in last two World Cups
- Only reached last eight at 2024 Copa América (also in North America)
- Manager: Carlo Ancelotti
- Strong attacking options mentioned: Rodrygo, Vinícius Júnior, Raphinha, Matheus Cunha, João Pedro

**5. Portugal**
- Never won a World Cup
- Won Euro 2016 and UEFA Nations League twice
- Manager: Roberto Martínez (noted as potential limiting factor)
- Failed to reach beyond last eight in previous four World Cups
- Key players: Cristiano Ronaldo, João Neves, Vitinha, Bruno Fernandes, Rafael Leão, Pedro Neto, João Félix

**4. England** (won in 1966)
- Only major triumph was 1966 World Cup
- Recent results: Euro 2020 and 2024 finals (lost both), 2018 World Cup 4th place, 2022 World Cup quarterfinals
- Manager: Thomas Tuchel (German coach, made winning start)
- Didn't concede a goal in eight qualifying matches

**3. France** (2018 world champions)
- Reached 2022 World Cup final (lost to Argentina)
- Manager: Didier Deschamps (described as pragmatic)
- "Blitzed their opponents" in qualification
- Key players: Kylian Mbappé, Michael Olise

**2. Spain** (2010 world champions)
- Manager: Luis de la Fuente
- Won 2022-23 Nations League and Euro 2024
- Failed to go beyond last 16 in previous three World Cups
- Key players: Lamine Yamal, Nico Williams

**1. Argentina** (defending champions)
- Won 2022 World Cup in Qatar (first since 1986)
- Lionel Messi featured (article notes 2026 could be his last World Cup, though sentence is cut off)

## Notable Context:
- Only 8 countries have ever won the World Cup since 1930
- The article notes the group stage has been completed (as of November 2025)
</Summary>

**FIFA Concerned Over Low Interest in the 2026 World Cup**
FIFA has expressed concern over the lack of enthusiasm surrounding the 2026 FIFA World Cup, noting that fan interest has been more subdued than expected despite the tournament's historic format. The 2026 World Cup will be the first to feature 48 national teams and will be hosted across three countries: the United States, Canada, and Mexico. However, a significant number of tickets remain unsold, raising questions about public engagement. With the tournament set to begin on June 11, 2026, and the final scheduled for July 19, 2026, FIFA hopes that interest will grow closer to kickoff and ticket sales will accelerate. Earlier reports indicated that FIFA had banned Atlético from registering new players until 2028.

**South African Sports Minister Predicts Victory Over Mexico Ahead of 2026 World Cup Debut**
Gayton McKenzie, South Africa's Minister of Sports, made a public statement ahead of the 2026 FIFA World Cup opening match between Mexico and South Africa, declaring that South Africa would win. The match, set to take place at the historic Estadio Azteca, recalls their 2010 encounter, which ended in a 1-1 draw. McKenzie emphasized the pressure on Mexico, noting the presence of 92,000 spectators and millions of supporters, which he described as a disadvantage for the home team. He asserted that South Africa is a serious threat to Mexico, aiming to motivate the national squad ahead of the historic 48-team World Cup tournament. The announcement was made on February 17, 2026, according to El Universal.

**Vinicius Surprises by Revealing His Favorites to Win the 2026 World Cup**
Vinicius Jr. revealed in an interview with Spanish streamer Ibai Llanos that his favorite teams to win the 2026 FIFA World Cup are Portugal, Spain, France, and Argentina, stating they have stronger squads and have retained key players from the previous World Cup. He emphasized that these teams' stability and quality make a significant difference. Vinicius also expressed confidence in Real Madrid coach Carlo Ancelotti, saying Ancelotti has transformed the team’s image, improved performance, and boosted team happiness. He noted Ancelotti’s repeated assurance that 'we are going to win this World Cup.' Despite Brazil’s last World Cup victory in 2002, Vinicius did not list Brazil as a favorite, acknowledging the nation’s long title drought. The interview was published on February 17, 2026.

**Djokovic Makes Bold Prediction for 2026 World Cup: Portugal to Defeat Mexico in Final**
Novak Djokovic, the tennis legend, made a bold prediction about the 2026 FIFA World Cup during a conversation with Jordanian content creator Mohamed Adnan. He stated that Portugal would win the tournament, defeating Mexico in the final. Djokovic emphasized the daring nature of his prediction, saying, 'I’m being bold: Portugal. Portugal will beat Mexico in the final.' He defended his choice by noting that Portugal's campaign could mark the end of Cristiano Ronaldo's international career, adding emotional weight to the scenario. The final matchup would feature Portugal against a European playoff qualifier, with potential opponents including the Czech Republic, Ireland, Denmark, and North Macedonia. Despite the unconventional nature of the prediction, Djokovic argued that the path to the final could be accessible due to home advantage and a favorable route. The statement quickly went viral on social media, drawing attention for its audacity and timing following the group stage draw.

**Finalissima 2026: Argentina vs Spain preview, date, venue & betting odds**
The 2026 Finalissima will be held on Friday, March 27, 2026, at Lusail Stadium in Qatar, the same venue where Argentina won the 2022 FIFA World Cup. The match features Argentina, defending Copa America champions, against Spain, the 2024 UEFA European Championship winners. Argentina, led by captain Lionel Messi, enters as 13/5 outsiders, while Spain are slight 11/10 favorites. The Finalissima is a single 90-minute match with no extra time; if tied, the winner is decided by a penalty shootout. The game will feature VAR, goalline technology, and semi-automated offside technology, with a referee jointly appointed by CONMEBOL and UEFA. Spain qualified for the Finalissima by winning Euro 2024, defeating England 2-1 in the Berlin final, and had a strong 2026 World Cup qualifying campaign, losing only once in six group matches. Argentina secured their spot by winning the 2024 Copa America, claiming their record 16th title with a 1-0 extra-time win over Colombia in Florida. The match marks a key rivalry showdown, with Spain having previously defeated Argentina 6-1 in a 2018 friendly and 4-1 in an earlier encounter. Argentina seeks revenge and aims to extend a three-game winning streak, including a 2-0 win over Angola in November. Historically, the last four meetings between the two teams have all featured at least three goals and both sides scoring, suggesting another high-scoring, fast-paced contest in Lusail.

**Who has qualified for the FIFA World Cup 2026™**
The FIFA World Cup 2026™ will be hosted by the United States, Mexico, and Canada, marking the first time the tournament expands to 48 teams. The article details all 48 qualified nations, including automatic qualifiers (USA, Mexico, Canada) and teams that earned spots through regional qualification. Key qualification changes include increased quotas: Asia (8 teams, +4), Africa (9, +4), North/Central America and Caribbean (6, +3), Europe (16, +3), South America (6, +2), and Oceania (1, +1). Notable qualifiers include Argentina (top of CONMEBOL), Brazil (5th in CONMEBOL), Portugal (top of UEFA Group J), and Norway (undefeated in UEFA group). The article provides detailed trivia and historical performances for each nation, such as Lionel Messi's record 26 World Cup appearances, Cristiano Ronaldo scoring in five editions, and Germany's four World Cup titles. The event will be broadcast live, free, and exclusive on SBS, SBS VICELAND, and SBS On Demand in Australia.

**Vinicius Jr picks best teams at 2026 World Cup as he delivers verdict on Cristiano Ronaldo-led Portugal and Lionel Messi's Argentina**
Vinicius Jr. has identified Portugal, Spain, France, and Argentina as the top four teams ahead of the 2026 FIFA World Cup, which will be jointly hosted by the United States, Canada, and Mexico from June 11 to July 19, 2026. The Real Madrid forward cited their consistency and strong squad continuity since the last World Cup as key reasons. Argentina, the reigning champions after winning the 2022 final against France on penalties, are led by Lionel Messi, who is playing in his final World Cup. Portugal, captained by 41-year-old Cristiano Ronaldo—playing his last World Cup—remains a strong contender despite never having won the tournament. Spain, the current European champions, boast a talented young squad, while France, the 2018 champions, reached the 2022 final before losing to Argentina on penalties. In a separate statement, former Manchester United defender Patrice Evra stated he prefers Cristiano Ronaldo over Lionel Messi, emphasizing Ronaldo’s work ethic over Messi’s talent, noting their 121 joint appearances as teammates and a 4-3 record in head-to-head matches. Evra also recorded a 1-3 record against Messi in five encounters.

**When and Where Is the 2026 World Cup Final?**
The 2026 FIFA World Cup will be the first edition with 48 teams and 104 matches, hosted across three countries: the United States, Mexico, and Canada. The tournament will run from June 11 to July 19, 2026, returning to the traditional mid-year schedule in the Northern Hemisphere summer. The final will be held on Sunday, July 19, 2026, at the New York New Jersey Stadium in the Meadowlands complex, which has a capacity of approximately 82,500 spectators and is one of the largest stadiums in the United States. This venue will host a total of eight matches, including five group stage games—such as Brazil vs. Morocco (Group C), France vs. Senegal (Group I), Norway vs. Senegal (Group I), Ecuador vs. Germany (Group E), and Panama vs. England (Group L)—two knockout stage matches (a Round of 16 on June 30 and an Round of 8 on July 5), and the final. The semifinals will be played in the United States, with the third-place match on July 18 in Miami. The tournament will feature 12 groups of four teams each, with the top two from each group and the eight best third-place teams advancing to the knockout stage. The champion will play eight matches, one more than in the previous 32-team format used in Qatar 2022.

**A Supercomputer Predicts the Winner of the 2026 FIFA World Cup**
The AI-powered supercomputer from the platform Opta predicts that Spain, led by coach Luis de la Fuente, will win the 2026 FIFA World Cup, with a 17% probability. France is second with a 14.1% chance, and England follows with 11.8%. Argentina, captained by Lionel Messi, has a projected win probability of only 8.7%, according to reports from Spain's Marca newspaper. **Surprise Prediction: AI Giant Forecasts Spain as 2026 World Cup Winner**
The 2026 FIFA World Cup, to be held in June for the first time across three countries—USA, Canada, and Mexico—is generating global anticipation. According to the advanced AI system from Opta, Spain is predicted to win the tournament with a 17% chance, followed by France at 14.1% and England at 11.8%. Argentina, led by Lionel Messi, has a lower projected chance of 8.7%. Opta's predictions are based on team performance data, probability analysis, and simulations of potential match outcomes. Spain, seeking its second World Cup title after 2010, enters the tournament with high morale following victories in UEFA Euro 2024 and reaching the final of the UEFA Nations League 2024–25. Head coach Luis de la Fuente, who took charge in December 2022 after leading Spain’s U19 and U21 teams to success, succeeded Luis Enrique after Spain’s early exit from the 2022 World Cup. This marks Spain’s 17th World Cup appearance.

**Supercomputer Predicts Who Will Win the 2026 World Cup**
The analytical portal Football Meets Data used artificial intelligence to simulate 100,000 possible scenarios for the 2026 FIFA World Cup, assessing the chances of nearly every qualified or qualifying team. As of December 4, 2025, Spain is the top favorite with a 22% probability of winning, followed by reigning world champions Argentina (14%), France (9%), England (8%), and Brazil and Colombia (5% each). Portugal has a 4% chance, while the Netherlands, Ecuador, Mexico, Croatia, and Norway each have 3%. Germany, Uruguay, Switzerland, Japan, and Canada are each rated at 2%, and Morocco, Belgium, the USA, Senegal, Austria, and Paraguay are each assigned 1%. Most other teams, including many Asian and African nations and those in intercontinental playoffs, are below 1%. The model considers recent results, individual player performance, team ratings, squad depth, and 'probabilistic indices' measuring long-term team stability. These projections are preliminary and may change after the draw and early tournament matches. Ukraine has not yet secured qualification; they will face Sweden in the playoff semifinal (March 26, 2026), with the winner facing the winner of the Poland-Albania matchup. If Ukraine qualifies, the AI still rates their chances of winning the tournament as symbolic, placing them among teams not considered serious contenders.

**AI Predicts World Cup 2026 Winner and Arab Nations' Chances**
According to global statistics network Opta, which uses computer models based on thousands of equations and technical criteria, Spain is the top contender to win the 2026 FIFA World Cup, with a 17% probability. France follows with 14.1%, England with 11.8%, Argentina (defending champions) with 8.7%, Germany with 7.1%, and Portugal with 6.6%. Brazil is seventh at 5.6%, followed by the Netherlands at 5.2% and Norway at 2.3%. Other teams include Colombia (2%), Belgium (1.9%), Uruguay (1.7%), Mexico (1.3%), Croatia (1.1%), Ecuador (1%), Japan (0.9%), the United States (0.9%), Switzerland (0.7%), Senegal (0.6%), Austria (0.6%), Côte d'Ivoire (0.5%), Canada (0.4%), Paraguay (0.4%), and Ghana (0.4%). Among Arab nations, Morocco leads with 1.1%, Egypt and Algeria each at 0.3% (same as South Korea), Tunisia at 0.2%, Saudi Arabia and Qatar at 0.1%, and Jordan at 0.0%. The lowest-probability teams include Jordan, Curaçao, and Haiti at 0.0%, and Saudi Arabia, New Zealand, Qatar, Panama, and Cape Verde at 0.1%.

**AI Predicts World Cup Champions Until the End of the 21st Century**
Grok AI has predicted the winners of the FIFA World Cup from 2026 to 2098, presenting a series of unexpected outcomes. The company forecasts that Spain will win the 2026 World Cup by defeating defending champions Argentina 2-1 in the final. Brazil will claim the title in 2030, beating France 3-1, avenging their 1998 final loss. France will win in 2034, defeating Germany 2-0, while England will triumph in 2038 by beating Brazil 1-0. Nigeria will become the first African nation to win the tournament in 2042, defeating Argentina 2-1. Germany will win in 2046, beating Spain 3-2. Argentina will return to the top in 2050, with Lionel Messi at age 63 defeating Portugal, as Cristiano Ronaldo turns 65. The United States will win for the first time in 2054, beating Mexico 2-1. Japan will become the first Asian champion in 2058, defeating France 1-0. Italy will win the 2062 final, defeating Brazil 2-1, ending Brazil’s 100-year championship drought. Morocco will become the first Arab nation to win in 2066, defeating England 3-2. Brazil will repeat their 2002 final victory over Germany in 2070, winning 4-2. Australia will win in 2074, beating Spain 2-1. Portugal will win in 2078, defeating France 3-2, just seven years before Ronaldo’s 100th birthday. Senegal will win in 2082, beating Argentina 1-0. The Netherlands will triumph in 2086, defeating Italy 3-1. Mexico will win in 2090, beating the USA 2-1. India will win in 2094, defeating Brazil 2-2 in regulation and winning on penalties. Finally, Germany will win the 2098 World Cup, defeating Portugal 2-0 in the final. These predictions are based on AI modeling and are not grounded in current performance or real-world data.

**Opta's AI Predicts Spain as Favorite to Win 2026 World Cup, with France and England in Contention**
Prior to the draw for the 2026 FIFA World Cup, Opta's AI has released its projections for the tournament, which will feature 48 teams across the United States, Canada, and Mexico from June 11 to July 19, 2026. According to Opta's artificial intelligence model, Spain is the top favorite with a 17% chance of winning, led by Lamine Yamal. France ranks second with a 14.1% chance of victory, followed by England at 11.8%, and defending champion Argentina at 8.7%. All other nations have less than 1% chance of winning the tournament. Michael Olise and the French national team are highlighted as key contenders in the AI's forecast.

**Supercomputer Predicts 2026 World Cup Winner Before Draw**
The Opta supercomputer has predicted the most likely winners of the 2026 FIFA World Cup before the group stage draw, assigning probabilities to each nation based on current form, squad quality, and historical performance. Spain is favored with a 17% chance, praised for their balanced roster, European Championship pedigree, and depth in midfield and attack. France follows closely with a 14.1% chance, driven by Kylian Mbappé's potential for a second title and their status as 2018 champions and 2022 runners-up. England is third with an 11.8% chance, reflecting confidence in Thomas Tuchel’s ability to end their 60-year title drought. Argentina, the defending champions and favorites among fans, are fourth at 8.7%, with Lionel Messi still a key figure despite the team’s reliance on a similar squad to the 2022-winning side. Germany is fifth at 7.1%, Portugal sixth at 6.6%, and Brazil seventh at 5.6%, despite their past North American triumphs, due to inconsistent recent performances. The Netherlands, who have never won the World Cup, are given a 5.2% chance, while Norway (2.3%) and Colombia (2.0%) are ranked tenth and eleventh, respectively, with Norway's chances boosted by Erling Haaland’s form. The supercomputer also estimates a 3.7% chance that a playoff winner—particularly Italy—could claim the title. Among the host nations, Mexico has the best odds at 1.3%, despite never advancing beyond the quarterfinals, while the USMNT is given a 0.9% chance, below Morocco, Ecuador, and Japan. Canada has the lowest chance at 0.4%, less than Austria, Senegal, and the Ivory Coast, reflecting their limited World Cup history and poor past performances, having lost all three group games in both their 1986 and 2022 appearances.

**2026 World Cup: Spain Favored to Win According to Opta Predictions**
According to Opta's predictions, Spain has the highest chance of winning the 2026 FIFA World Cup, which will be hosted by Canada, the United States, and Mexico. Spain leads the rankings, followed by England with 11.8% chance, Argentina with 8.7%, Germany with 7.1%, Portugal with 6.6%, Brazil with 5.6%, and the Netherlands with 5.2%. England is seeking its first World Cup title since 1966. In contrast, Haiti has the lowest chance at 0.03%, followed by Curaçao and Jordan, both at 0.04%. The group stage draw is scheduled for Friday in Washington, with the final set for July 19, 2026.
